title: How to Close Apps on Android

steps.title: Open the Recent Apps list on your Android.
steps.content: Open the Recent Apps list on your Android. If you're using Android 10 or above, swipe up from the bottom of the home screen, hold your finger there, and then let go. [1] X Research source Depending on your model, you may have to tap an icon instead of swiping—you'll often see three vertical lines at the bottom-right or bottom-left corner of the screen, if so. On other models, the icon may be a may be a square or a set of cascading rectangles.

steps.title: Scroll through the apps.
steps.content: Scroll through the apps. Keep swiping left or right (or up or down) until you find the app you want to close.

steps.title: Swipe the app off the screen.
steps.content: Swipe the app off the screen. Where you need to drag it varies. If you scrolled through the app list vertically, swipe the app left or right to close it. If the list scrolls horizontally, swipe the app up off the screen. This action closes the app. You may be able to tap an X in the top corner of the app's window instead of swiping away the app. To close all open apps at once, tap Close all or Clear all . [2] X Research source

steps.title: Open your Android's Settings.
steps.content: Open your Android's Settings. Tap the Settings app icon, which is the gear icon in your app list. You can also swipe down from the top of the screen (you may have to use two fingers) and then tap the gear icon in the top-right corner. Use this method if you've already closed the app in the Recent Apps list but are still having app or performance issues.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap Apps or Apps & Notifications.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap Apps or Apps & Notifications . Depending on your manufacturer and version of Android, you'll see one of these options on your Settings menu. This will open a list of your installed apps.

steps.title: Choose the option to display all apps.
steps.content: Choose the option to display all apps. Depending on your Android, you may not be viewing a list of all installed apps. If you see a three-dot menu at the top-right corner, tap it, and then select Show system apps or Show all apps to refresh the app list.

steps.title: Tap the app you want to close.
steps.content: Tap the app you want to close. This displays information about the app.

steps.title: Tap Stop or Force Stop.
steps.content: Tap Stop or Force Stop . A confirmation message will appear asking if you want to close the app. [3] X Research source The confirmation message you see may also inform you that force-closing an app can cause the app to misbehave—this is because stopping an open app while it's running could prevent it from finishing operations or saving files.

steps.title: Tap Force Stop or OK to confirm.
steps.content: Tap Force Stop or OK to confirm. This forces the selected app to close and halt all of its background processes.

steps.title: Open your Android's Settings.
steps.content: Open your Android's Settings. Tap the Settings app icon, which resembles a gear. Occasionally, closing an app will leave a service hanging that hogs resources. You can usually close the app's service(s) to resolve the issue. A service is a background process that doesn't have an app-like user interface. [4] X Research source It's rare that anyone other than a developer would need to shut down a service, which is why this feature is hidden in the Developer Options section of your Settings.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap About phone or About tablet.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap About phone or About tablet . One of these options will appear in the Settings menu. Depending on your Android, you may have to tap System before you'll see an About option.

steps.title: Scroll down to the "Build number" heading.
steps.content: Scroll down to the "Build number" heading. It should be at the very bottom of the menu.

steps.title: Tap the "Build number" heading 7 to 10 times.
steps.content: Tap the "Build number" heading 7 to 10 times. Once you've tapped this heading enough times in a row, you will see a message that says "You are now a developer!" (or similar). [5] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the "Back" button and select Developer options.
steps.content: Tap the "Back" button and select Developer options . It's the new menu that now appears near the About phone or About tablet option.

steps.title: Tap the Developer options menu.
steps.content: Tap the Developer options menu. It's usually near the bottom of the menu.

steps.title: Find and tap Running services.
steps.content: Find and tap Running services . It should be near the top of the Developer Options page, but your Android's Running services option's location may vary. On some Androids, this option will be Processes or Process Stats .

steps.title: Tap the service you want to close.
steps.content: Tap the service you want to close. The open running services will appear in the order of most RAM-intensive to least. Keep in mind that many services are required to keep your Android running, so closing the wrong service may crash or reboot your phone or tablet. Avoid stopping any apps labeled "Google" or "Android" for best results.

steps.title: Tap Stop.
steps.content: Tap Stop . The selected service and any associated apps will stop running. You may have to tap OK or Stop to confirm this step. The service may restart automatically if you re-open its associated app or reboot your phone or tablet.
